comment:
A higher level `PostgreSQL`:idx: database wrapper. This interface 
## is implemented for other databases too.

name: FWriteDb
description: effect that denotes a write operation

name: sql
description:
constructs a TSqlQuery from the string query. This is supposed to be used as a raw-string-literal modifier: sql"update user set counter = counter + 1"

If assertions are turned off, it does nothing. If assertions are turned on, later versions will check the string for valid syntax.

name: dbError
description: raises an EDb exception with message <cite>msg</cite>.

name: TryExec
description: tries to execute the query and returns true if successful, false otherwise.
code:
proc TryExec*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): bool {.
    tags: [FReadDB, FWriteDb].}

name: Exec
description: executes the query and raises EDB if not successful.
code:
proc Exec*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]) {.
    tags: [FReadDB, FWriteDb].}

name: FastRows
description: executes the query and iterates over the result dataset. This is very fast, but potenially dangerous: If the for-loop-body executes another query, the results can be undefined. For Postgres it is safe though.
code:
iterator FastRows*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): TRow {.
    tags: [FReadDB].}

name: getRow
description: retrieves a single row. If the query doesn't return any rows, this proc will return a TRow with empty strings for each column.
code:
proc getRow*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): TRow {.
    tags: [FReadDB].}

name: GetAllRows
description: executes the query and returns the whole result dataset.
code:
proc GetAllRows*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): seq[
    TRow] {.tags: [FReadDB].}

name: Rows
description: same as <cite>FastRows</cite>, but slower and safe.
code:
iterator Rows*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): TRow {.
    tags: [FReadDB].}

name: GetValue
description: executes the query and returns the first column of the first row of the result dataset. Returns "" if the dataset contains no rows or the database value is NULL.
code:
proc GetValue*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): string {.
    tags: [FReadDB].}

name: TryInsertID
description: executes the query (typically "INSERT") and returns the generated ID for the row or -1 in case of an error. For Postgre this adds RETURNING id to the query, so it only works if your primary key is named id.
code:
proc TryInsertID*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): int64 {.
    tags: [FWriteDb].}

name: InsertID
description: executes the query (typically "INSERT") and returns the generated ID for the row. For Postgre this adds RETURNING id to the query, so it only works if your primary key is named id.
code:
proc InsertID*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): int64 {.
    tags: [FWriteDb].}

name: ExecAffectedRows
description: executes the query (typically "UPDATE") and returns the number of affected rows.
code:
proc ExecAffectedRows*(db: TDbConn; query: TSqlQuery; args: varargs[string, `$`]): int64 {.
    tags: [FReadDB, FWriteDb].}

name: Open
description:
opens a database connection. Raises EDb if the connection could not be established.

Clients can also use Postgres keyword/value connection strings to connect.

Example:

con = Open("", "", "", "host=localhost port=5432 dbname=mydb")

See http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-CONNSTRING for more information.

Note that the connection parameter is not used but exists to maintain the nimrod db api.
code: proc Open*(connection, user, password, database: string): TDbConn {.tags: [FDb].}
